They knew they‚Äôd be held accountable for the projects success and failures, which, at peak hype has very little to do with their execution anymore. 

Gain millions and lose your sanity or walk away? The choice is obvious to me

If you want to run a project, think about it in a 5-10 year horizon instead.

No amount of money can bring you peace, security, and freedom. It can help, but only to an extent.

This turns into pressure to perform, to release updates that hype the community, to compete in the never ending arena of NFT twitter

The strings: your community (aka investors) expects a ROI. 

Even if it‚Äôs all about the ‚Äúvibes‚Äù early on, take a look at discords when a project starts to nose dive

While the average nft project can mint out overnight and earn your 7 figures+ of money, it‚Äôs not all that rosey

The money you get has a lot of strings attached to it

Founder burnout is real. 

In a sea of quick flips, dopamine highs, and hype, we often forget about the creators and expectations placed on them.

47/ So the next time someone asks why NFTs are worth so much, send them this thread - NFTs are so much more than just JPEGs. 

They're something that help people fulfil their core emotional and human needs in so many ways, and it‚Äôs hard to put a price on that.

46/ In NFTs, we found belonging and community.

We found connection when so many of us were deprived of it - which, at the end of the day, is really what it means to be human.

Without each other to share experiences with, life is empty.
45/ What nobody could have predicted was that NFTs would change so many lives by offering financial security and the freedom to live life on their own terms.

44/ Fundamentally, humans have a craving and desire to want to feel safe, belong, and to feel important.

In 2021, in an unstable period in history, many of us found that in NFT communities
43/ But through a psychologists lens, it's evident that NFTs aren't only about money, ego (cc: @guardianartbot) and they certainly aren't just JPEGs https://t.co/phy7rZIzYU

42/ Round off Maslow's pyramid, the last level is "self-actualization"

In Maslow's perspective, that is the peak state that any human can reach.

What "peak state" actually is looks different for everyone, so it's not my place to give examples here https://t.co/aRdDpcdY85

41/ and of course, this is where @foreverapesnft fits into this

we're creating luxury physicals for BAYC and the wider NFT community, starting with a high-quality coffee table book

https://t.co/qFybzbLzdo

40/ Or the apple watch + Bored Ape combo which is becoming notorious

https://t.co/Ua4Dtsgayy

39/ But we've seen other forms of IRL status signaling, particularly with BAYC. 

Like this BAYC Rolex watch https://t.co/JvlSzU0jFK

38/ Esteem needs are also where status comes into play. 

I‚Äôve written about pfps becoming status symbols on Twitter, which is a big part of the value of @boredapeyc

https://t.co/Djk7HPQTo5

37/ How people channelled their creativity was unique to them:

some built valuable tools for the community (@niftytailor), some created banners (@nftgerry), and others built a totally new universe like Jenkins

https://t.co/fHDAXxQEuI

36/ Naturally, BAYC creators have spent more time in thriving mode vs survival mode

When money isn't a concern, your brain switches from survival, fear-based emotions (i.e. risk-averse) to putting yourself out there, taking chances and building https://t.co/EriixMhtMY

35/ @boredapeyc was the first NFT project with a high floor. 

BAYC members experienced the safety to go full-time in NFTs first.

Even though cryptopunks was the most valuable at the time, these were inaccessible to most people by early 2021

https://t.co/f5y5GbYTLp

34/ Esteem needs are all about mastery, achieving something, and gaining status and respect among people.

With this lens, it makes complete sense why we see so many creators coming from BAYC specifically (and not as many from cool cats, doodles etc)

33/ and with that safety blanket, many quit their jobs to go full time into NFTs.

Your ability to pay your rent was no longer tied to you working a 9-5, freeing up your time to explore your creativity.

and with that, level 4 in Maslow's pyramid was unlocked: Esteem https://t.co/8lLKJRYhky

32/ Then, NFTs solved people's "safety" needs in a big way

The ape you had purchased for ~$600 was now worth $50K only a few months later

While that isn't necessarily "life-changing" in a grand way, it did give people a safety blanket they didn't have before.
31/ So, NFTs and communities solved people's love/belonging needs that weren't being met due to pandemic restrictions.
30/ At a time when people needed connection and belonging the most, here came these funny apes making monkey sounds in Clubhouse rooms https://t.co/ZAfujJg6fd

29/ pfp NFTs projects like @boredapeyc helped people feel like a part of a group, a collective.

In the middle of isolation and lockdowns, you had a group of people that you could connect with digitally on Twitter, Discord and Clubhouse/Spaces
28/ and that energy - the human desire to connect with others, to feel like a part of a group which was missing from so many people's day to day lives - parlayed right into pfp NFTs
27/ For the first time in a long time, you were able to connect and talk to people with shared interests, like you would IRL

26/ Collectively, we all yearned for the human connection we were used to, pre-lockdown.

When we could hang out with friends, go on dates and meet new people.

It's not a coincidence that Clubhouse took the world by storm around this time https://t.co/oloSXEZHyc

25/ Chaos can shake your foundation

If you lose your job because of lockdowns, your safety needs are at risk - can you still pay rent?

and if you're unable to see family or lived alone during lockdown, your love and belonging needs weren't being met

24/ and we're back

most of us degens are likely at the "love and belonging" stage in Maslow's hierarchy - we're much well of than the majority of the world

But in 2021, with the lockdowns and not being able to see loved ones, lost jobs, the world was chaotic, to say the least https://t.co/vygCH0wDfj
https://t.co/TStgWzdB45
23/ Hey, 23 tweets in... meme break anyone? https://t.co/po27dGE2HA

22/ it's fair to say that most of us degens on apeing into NFTs have our physiological + safety needs met at the very least.

Like, nobody sacrificed dinner so they could mint @pixelmon's

...right? https://t.co/z7IuveTWpj

21/ and of course, nothing in life is linear. 

So you can go from a higher level on Maslow's pyramid, back down to a lower level when hardships hit, like divorce, losing a job, or war üíôüíõ

20/ Now, the theory states that to "level up" in life, you need to meet the needs of the previous level

As in, you won't care about love and belonging if you don't have enough food to eat

It's why the theory is best visualized as a pyramid. Something each of us climbs up https://t.co/RepiIhQCVO

19/ 

4) Esteem: Esteem for one-self through achievement and gaining respect from others (status, prestige)

5) Self-actualization: The highest level on the pyramid, it's the realization of a person's full potential, to seek growth and become all that you can be

18/ The 5 core needs are as follows:

1) Physiological: basic survival needs like food, shelter

2) Safety: Having order, predictability, and emotional and financial security

3) Love and belongingness: friendship, intimacy, trust with others and a group

17/ To explain, allow me to introduce our friend Abraham Maslow, a 20th century Psychologist.

Best known for his theory called "Maslow's hierarchy of needs" which states that every human has 5 core needs https://t.co/R6MSLzmDfb

16/ This story is more common than you'd think, not just for BAYC members but for people that have done well with NFTs overall

Life has changed for so many with NFTs - but it's not just about money in the bank.

There is a deep psychological change that has happened
